text: 1. This (nishkevalya- s astra) becomes perfect as a thousand of B ri hatî verses. In this thousand of B ri hatîs there are one thousand one hundred and twenty-five Anush t ubhs. For the smaller is contained in the larger.

text: 2. This has been said by a Ri shi (Rv. VIII, 76, 12):--

text: 3. 'A speech of eight feet;'--because there are eight feet of four syllables each in the Anush t ubh.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. 'Of nine corners;'--because the B ri hatî becomes nine-cornered (having nine feet of four syllables each).

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. 'Touching the truth;'--because speech (Anush t ubh) is truth, touched by the verse (B ri hatî) 1 .

text: 6. 'He (the Hot ri ) makes the body out of Indra;--'for out of this thousand of B ri hatî verses turned into Anush t ubhs, and therefore out of Prâ n a as connected with Indra 2 , and out of the B ri hatî (which is Prâ n a), he makes speech, that is Anush t ubh, as a body 3 .

text: 8. A Ri k verse, a gâthâ 1 , a kumbyâ 2 are measured (metrical). A Ya g us line, an invocation, and general remarks 3 , these are not measured (they are in prose). A Sâman, or any portion (parvan) of it, is music. Om is true, Na is untrue.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 9. What is true (Om) is the flower and fruit of speech. He is able to become celebrated and of good report, for he speaks the true (Om), the flower and fruit of speech.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 10. Now the untrue is the root 4 of speech, and as a tree whose root is exposed dries up and perishes, thus a man who says what is untrue exposes his root, dries up and perishes. Therefore one should not say what is untrue, but guard oneself from it.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 11. That syllable Om (yes) goes forward (to the first cause of the world) and is empty. Therefore if a man says Om (yes) to everything, then that (which he gives away) is wanting to him here 5 . If he says Om (yes) to everything, then he would empty himself, and would not be capable of any enjoyments.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 12. That syllable Na (no) is full for oneself 6 . If a man says No to everything, then his reputation

text: 13. Therefore let a man give at the proper time only, not at the wrong time. Thus he unites the true and the untrue, and from the union of those two he grows, and becomes greater and greater.

text: 14. He who knows this speech of which this (the mahaduktha) is a development, he is clever. A is the whole of speech, and manifested through different kinds of contact (mutes) and of wind (sibilants), it becomes manifold and different.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive

text: 15. Speech if uttered in a whisper is breath, if spoken aloud, it is body. Therefore (if whispered) it is almost hidden, for what is incorporeal is almost hidden, and breath is incorporeal. But if spoken aloud, it is body, and therefore it is perceptible, for body is perceptible.
